titleStmt.title: Event-triggered leader-following consensus for multi-agent systems with semi-Markov switching topologies

affiliation.orgName: School of Control Science and Engineering
North China Institute of Astronautic Engineering
State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation for Industrial Process

analytic.title: Event-triggered leader-following consensus for multi-agent systems with semi-Markov switching topologies

biblStruct.note: Received 9 February 2018 Revised 9 April 2018 Accepted 15 April 2018

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Event-triggered scheme Semi-Markov switching topologies Multi-agent systems Leader-following consensus

div.p: This paper investigates the event-triggered leader-following consensus problem for a multi-agent system with semi-Markov switching topologies. A sampled-data-based eventtriggered transmission scheme is introduced to reduce unnecessary communication. By modeling the switching of network topologies by a semi-Markov process and adopting an event-triggered transmission scheme, a new consensus protocol is proposed. Compared with the traditional Markovian switching topologies, the transition rates in the semi-Markov switching topologies are time-varying, which is more general and practicable. Through utilization of an appropriate Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional, some sufficient conditions are derived, which guarantee that the leader-following consensus can be achieved in mean-square sense. Moreover, the consensus gain matrices and parameter of the eventtriggered scheme can be efficiently solved out. Finally, a numerical example illustrates the effectiveness of the proposed design technique.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In recent years, distributed coordinated control of multi-agent systems has been studied extensively due to its broad applications in cooperative control of unmanned airborne vehicles [1] , automated highway systems [2] , distributed sensor networks [32] , etc. As an important issue in distributed coordinated control of multi-agent systems, consensus problem has received considerable attention [9,21,[26][27][28][29]35,36] , whose objective is to design a distributed consensus protocol such that the states of all agents converge to an agreement state by using only local information exchange. Specifically, when the agreement state is provided by a leader agent, the leader-following consensus problem arises [11,26,28] . In leader-following multi-agent systems, the leader is usually independent of the followers but has influence on the followers behaviors [14,15] . Thus, the objective of controlling a group of agents can be realized by controlling only the leader, which greatly simplifies the analysis and design of multi-agent systems and helps to save energy and reduce control costs [22] .

On the other hand, the event-triggered control strategy is an effective way to save communication and computation resources. Compared with a time-triggered strategy, data transmission and control updates in the event-triggered strategy are determined by an event-triggered condition. If the event condition is violated, which means that the measurement error

div.head: JID: INS
div.p: [m3Gsc; April 27, 2018;13:35 ] exceeds a threshold, control updates should be transmitted [39,40] . Hence, the event-triggered strategy can reduce unnecessary communication and computation resources [37] . For a multi-agent system, in order to reduce unnecessary communication, each agent is often equipped with an event-triggered processor, which decides whether or not data of agent should be broadcasted to the other agents. Up to date, many works on the event-triggered consensus have been reported [6,13,24,31] . In [6] , a decentralized event-triggered strategy has been proposed to decrease the number of the control updates, however, all agents need to monitor their neighbors' states continuously. Such continuous detection does not reduce over-consumption of communication. In order to overcome this limitation, some new event-triggered consensus algorithms with sampled-data event detection have been provided in [13,24] , where event-triggered condition is only required to be measured at sampling instants. In [43] , the event-based consensus of general linear multi-agent systems has been considered. An improved algorithm is proposed for determining event time sequences, which can reduce not only control updates, but also communication between neighboring agents. For more details on event-triggered control and consensus problems, we refer the reader to some recent survey papers [7,10,12] . Most of the above works focus on the multi-agent systems with fixed topology. However, in practical systems, the communication topology among agents may change over time, due to unknown abrupt phenomena such as sudden environmental changes, random failures and repairs of components. For the sake of describing this kind of time-varying topology, a simple method is that the time-varying topology is modeled as Markov switching topologies. So far, many works regarding multi-agent systems with Markov switching topologies have been reported in the literature; see, e.g., [9,23,25,34,41] and the references therein. However, the time-varying topology described by the Markov process has many limitations in applications, since the jump time of a Markov chain is, in general, exponentially distributed. Hence, the results on Markov switching topologies are conservative in some senses [19,20] . Very recently, some researchers have devoted their efforts to semi-Markov jump topologies [18,33] . Compared with conventional Markov switching topologies, the probability distribution of sojourn-time in semi-Markov switching topologies is relaxed from exponential distribution to a more general probability distribution, such as Weibull distribution, Gaussian distribution, etc. Hence, the semi-Markov switching topologies are more general than the conventional Markov switching topologies due to their relaxed conditions on the probability distributions. However, there are few results on the leader-following consensus of multi-agent systems with semi-Markov switching topologies [5] .

Motivated by the above discussion, this paper addresses the event-triggered consensus of leader-following multi-agent systems with semi-Markov switching topologies, where each agent has general linear dynamics. The main contributions are summarized as follows. (1) Compared with the existing results on event-triggered leader-following consensus, a new consensus protocol based on the sampled-data and semi-Markov switching topologies is proposed for leader-following multi-agent systems. (2) A sampled-data-based event-triggered transmission scheme is designed. The event-triggered condition is only required to be measured and calculated at sampling instants. (3) The Laplacian matrices of switching topologies are not required to be symmetric. This work is a natural continuation of our recent work [4] on second-order multi-agent systems without leader and semi-Markov switching topologies.

The following notations will be used throughout this paper, R n represents the n dimensional Euclidean space. I n denotes an n × n identity matrix, 0 denotes zero matrix with an appropriate dimension. diag { . . . } stands for a diagonal matrix. P > 0 ( P ≥ 0) means that P is symmetric and positive definite (semi-definite). The superscript "T " denotes matrix transposition and the asterisk " * " in a matrix is used to represent the term that is induced by symmetry. represents the Kronecker product.

E { •} stands for the mathematical exception operator. x refers to the Euclidean norm of vector x . We use col { x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x m } to denote the column vector x T 1 , x T 2 , . . . , x T m T .

div.head: Graph theory
div.p: In this paper, we use a directed graph G to describe the information exchange among N followers and a leader labeled by v 0 , where G consists of graph G, leader node v 0 and directed edges from leader v 0 to followers. G = ( V, E, A ) denotes a directed graph among the N followers, where
div.formula: V = { v 1 , v 2 , . . . , v N } is the set of N followers, E ⊆ V × V is the set of directed
div.p: edges, and A = a i j N×N is a weighted adjacency matrix. A directed edge ij in G is the ordered pair of nodes ( v i , v j ), where node v i can receive information from node v j . In this case, node v j is a neighbor of node v i and the neighbor index set of node v i is denoted by N i = j| v i , v j ∈ E . If i j ∈ E, then a ij > 0, otherwise a i j = 0 . Furthermore, we assume that a ii = 0 for all i . The Laplacian matrix of the directed graph G is defined as L = l i j N×N with l ii = j∈ N i a i j and l i j = -a i j , for i = j . A directed path in G from node v j to v i is a sequence of directed edge of the form
div.formula: v i , v i 1 , v i 1 , v i 2 , . . . , v i l , v j with distinct nodes v i k , k = 1 , 2 , . . . , l.
div.p: A directed graph is said to contain a directed spanning tree if there exists at least one node having a directed path to all other nodes. We assume that the leader does not receive any information from the followers, and the leader is a neighbor of only a part of the followers.
div.formula: A diagonal matrix B = diag { b 1 , b 2 , . . . ,

div.head: Problem formulation
div.p: Consider a leader-following multi-agent system with one leader and N followers. The dynamics of each agent is described by

where x i ( t ) ∈ R n and u i ( t ) ∈ R p are the state and control input of the i th agent, respectively; x 0 ( t ) ∈ R n is the state of the leader agent; A and B are constant matrices with appropriate dimensions.

In this paper, we introduce a distributed event-triggered consensus protocol, which not only reduces the communication between neighboring agents, but also guarantees that the multi-agent system (1) reaches consensus. For this purpose, an event-triggered detector is configured at each agent to decide when the agent should send its sampled-data to its neighbors. The event-triggered condition for the i th agent is defined as
div.formula: [ e i (t i k + lh )] T e i (t i k + lh ) ≤ δ i [ z i (t i k + lh )] T z i (t i k + lh ) , l = 1 , 2 , . . . ,(2)
div.p: where δ i > 0 is a threshold parameter, is a positive definite event-triggered matrices to be designed later, h is the sampling period, t i k is the k th event-triggered instant for agent i , and
div.formula: t i k + lh denote the currently sampled instant, e i (t i k + lh ) = x i (t i k ) - x i (t i k + lh ) , z i (t i k + lh ) = j∈ N i a i j [ x i (t i k ) -x j (t j k )] + b i ( x i (t i k ) -x 0 (t i k + lh )) , t j k = max { t | t ∈ { t j k , k = 0 , 1 , . . . } , t ≤ t i k + lh } .
div.p: For the sake of analysis, several assumptions are made as follows: (i) the sampling period for all agents is synchronized by a clock; (ii) each agent's state is periodically sampled, and the sampling time sequence is 0 , h, 2 h, . . . ; (iii) the sampleddata of agent i is transmitted to its neighbor only when the event-triggered condition ( 2) is violated, and the event-triggered time sequence of agent i is t i 0 , t i 1 , t i 2 , . . . , wher e t i 0 = 0 is the initial time.
Remark 1. It follows from above assumptions that the event-triggered time sequence is a subsequence of the sampling time sequence, namely
. . } , which means that the minimum inter-event time min
div.formula: k t i k +1 -t i k , ∀ i, is
div.p: lower bounded by the sampling period h . Hence, Zeno behavior does not occur.
Based on the foregoing discussion, we consider the following consensus protocol:
div.formula: u i (t) = -K(r (t)) j∈ N i a i j (r (t )) x i ( t i k ) -x j ( t j k ) + b i (r(t)) x i ( t i k ) -x 0 ( qh ) , i = 1 , 2 , . . . , N,(3)
where t ∈ [ t i k , t i k +1 ) ∩ [ qh, (q + 1) h ) , q is an integer; K ( r ( t )
div.p: ) is feedback gain matrix to be designed later; a ij ( r ( t )) is the ( i, j )th entry of the adjacency matrix A (r(t)) ; b i ( r ( t )) ≥ 0 is the coupling weight between agent i and the leader, and is defined as follows: if agent i can receive information from the leader, b i ( r ( t )) > 0, otherwise, b i (r(t)) = 0 ; r ( t ) denotes a continuous-time discrete-state semi-Markov process taking values in a finite set S = { 1 , 2 , . . . , s } .
The evolution of the semi-Markov process r ( t ) is governed by the following probability transitions:
div.formula: P r { r ( t + ϑ ) = n | r ( t ) = m } = λ mn ( ϑ ) ϑ + o ( ϑ ) , m = n, 1 + λ mn ( ϑ ) ϑ + o ( ϑ ) , m = n, (4
div.p: where ϑ is the sojourn time representing the time duration between two successive jumps, o ( ϑ) is little -o notation defined by lim ϑ→ 0 o ( ϑ ) ϑ = 0 , λ mn ( ϑ ) ≥ 0 is the transition rate from mode m at time t to mode n at time t + ϑ when m = n and
div.formula: λ mm ( ϑ ) = -s n =1 ,n = m λ mm ( ϑ ) .
div.p: Remark 2. It should be pointed out that a novel consensus protocol (3) has been proposed, which not only depends on the event-triggered condition, but also on semi-Markov switching topologies. The purpose of this design is to reduce unnecessary communication while capturing more time-varying dynamics of the network topology. In addition, the transition rate λ mn ( ϑ) in ( 4) is time varying and depends on ϑ. When λ mn ( ϑ) ≡ λ mn , the semi-Markov process simplifies to a classical Markov process.
In addition, the next broadcast instant t i k +1 of agent i is determined by
div.formula: t i k +1 = t i k + min l≥1 { lh | e i (t i k + lh ) T e i (t i k + lh ) > δ i z i (t i k + lh ) T z i (t i k + lh ) } . (5

div.head: Remark 4.
div.p: Theorem 2 provides a sufficient condition to guarantee consensus for the multi-agent system (2) with eventtriggered condition and semi-Markov switching topologies. Furthermore, the consensus gain matrices and the eventtriggered parameter matrices are all obtained.

Since λ mn ( ϑ) in ( 31) is time-varying, the sufficient conditions in Theorems 1 and 2 are not linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) conditions, which can not be solved by LMI toolbox in MATLAB. In order to overcome this difficulty, the following theorem is given.
Please cite this article as: J. Dai, G.

div.p: Proof. Following the same line of proof as in Theorem 2 of [17] , Theorem 3 can be easily proved. Thus, the proof is omitted here.

Remark 5. In order to obtain a set of LMIs, λ mn (ϑ ) ∈ [ λ mn , λ mn ] was used in the proof of Theorem 3 . It should be pointed out that the above theorem are relatively conservative. In order to reduce the conservatism, [17] introduced a sojourn-time partition method that partitions the sojourn-time ϑ into K sections and denotes λ mn, k and λ mn,k as the lower and upper bounds of the transition rates during the k th section ( k = 1 , 2 , . . . , K), respectively.
With the sojourn-time partition method, a less conservative criterion is obtained.
Corollary 1. For given scalars h > 0 and μ > 0, if Assumption 1 holds and there exist matrices

div.p: In contrast to the result given in Theorem 3, Corollary 1 presents a less conservative result since more of the transition rate information is used in the analysis as the partition number of the sojourn time increases.

div.head: Numerical example
div.p: In this section, a power network example is provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed design method. The microgrid is considered as a multi-agent system, where each distributed generator (DG) is an agent. The secondary voltage control of microgrid can be formulated as a consensus tracking problem, where all DGs try to synchronize their terminal voltage amplitude to prespecified reference values. Here, we assume the same model for the DGs described in [3,42] ˙ Please cite this article as: J. Dai, G. In order to achieve consensus tracking, communication between neighbor DGs is required. The use of modern network information and communication technologies typically adds efficiency and scalability. However, it can also increase the vulnerability to mistakes from human operators, failures in equipment,and cyber-attacks. Therefore, the communication network among the DGs is modeled by a group of directed switching topologies, which are shown in Fig. 1 . The agent indexed by 0 is referred as the leader(reference generator) and agents indexed by 1, 2, 3 and 4 are called the followers. Suppose that the directed switching topologies are governed by a semi-Markov process with three modes. Note that every possible graph has a directed spanning tree with the leader as the root node. In addition, assume that all the weights are equal to one.
div.formula: x i = A x i + B u i ˙ x 0 = A x 0 , where A = 0 1 0 0 , B = 0 1 , x 0 = x re f 0 , and x i = x i 1 x i 2 , i = 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 .

div.head: ARTICLE IN PRESS
div.p: From the Fig. 1 , we can obtain the corresponding Laplacian matrices L (1), L (2), L (3) and the leader adjacency matrices B (1) , B (2) , B (3) as follows:

Please cite this article as: J. Dai, G. Set the sampling period h = 0 . 1 and the event-triggered parameters δ 1 = 0 . 01 , δ 2 = 0 . 005 , δ 3 = 0 . 01 , δ 4 = 0 . 015 . By solving the LMIs (32) and (38) in Theorem 3 with μ = 5 , we can obtain the event-triggered parameter matri- 3 , which implies that the number of the sampled-data transmission is reduced. In addition, the semi-Markov switching signal with three modes is given in Fig. 4 . The simulation results show that the leader-following consensus is achieved, which illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed design method.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, we have studied the event-triggered consensus problem for leader-following multi-agent systems with semi-Markov switching topologies. A novel event-triggered consensus protocol with semi-Markov switching topologies has been developed to reduce unnecessary communication while capturing more time-varying dynamics of the network topology. By constructing a mode-dependent Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional and employing the reciprocal convex combination method, some sufficient conditions have been proposed to ensure that the leader-following consensus can be achieved in mean-square sense. Furthermore, the consensus gain matrices and the event-triggered parameter matrices are all obtained. Finally, a numerical example is given to illustrate the effectiveness of the developed results.
